cs.DC, cs.CE, cs.NA, cs.SE, cs.SY. 

The paper deals with adaptive workflows for scientific simulations, which involves managing computational and data manipulation steps dynamically based on the state of the simulation. This is a problem that is relevant to several sub-fields of computer science, including distributed computing (cs.DC), computational engineering (cs.CE), numerical analysis (cs.NA), software engineering (cs.SE), and control systems (cs.SY). The paper specifically focuses on a method for detecting triggers in simulations of turbulent combustion, which involves analyzing data to identify critical phases of the simulation. This could be relevant to several sub-fields, including computer graphics (cs.GR), computer vision (cs.CV), and machine learning (cs.LG), but the focus on scientific simulations and the use of chemical explosive mode analysis (CEMA) suggests that the paper is more likely to belong to the aforementioned sub-fields.
